item.title: Why is it so hard for companies to protect your privacy?
item.description: Minh Nguyen, VP of Engineering at Transcend, joins Ryan for a conversation about the complexities of privacy and consent in tech, from the challenges organizations face in managing data privacy to the importance of consent management tools to the evolving landscape of privacy regulations.

item.title: Unlocking the Potential of Quantum Computing
item.description: A free Coursera course on quantum error correction, developed by Google Quantum AI, explains the importance of error correction in quantum computing and provides an overview of quantum errors.

item.title: The next chapter of the Gemini era for developers
item.description: Gemini 2.0 Flash has enhanced capabilities like multimodal outputs and native tool use, and introduces new coding agents to improve developer productivity, now available for testing in Google AI Studio.

item.title: Registration is Open for Google Cloud Next 2025
item.description: Google Cloud Next 2025, happening April 9-11 in Las Vegas, will feature expanded developer content, interactive experiences, and opportunities to connect with peers and Google experts.

item.title: Introducing the Android XR SDK Developer Preview
item.description: The Android XR SDK, a new platform for building extended reality (XR) experiences on Android, is now available for devs to try, and to give feedback.

item.title: Celebrating Flutter’s “Production Era”
item.description: Flutter is transitioning into its “production era,” marked by widespread developer adoption and success stories, including deeper iOS fidelity, seamless platform integration, and enhanced developer tools, making it a top choice for building apps at scale.

item.title: Apigee API hub is now generally available
item.description: Apigee API hub is a centralized repository for your entire API ecosystem, providing a single source of truth.

item.title: Build Go applications using Project IDX and the Gemini API
item.description: Learn how to build Go applications using Project IDX, an AI-assisted workspace for full-stack app development.

item.title: Dive Deep into Gemini: Explore Starter Apps in AI Studio
item.description: Explore three Gemini starter apps that provide developers with production ready tools to build AI-powered projects with open source functionalities like spatial analysis, and video interactions.

item.title: Celebrating innovation: Gemini API Developer Competition
item.description: Explore innovative projects from the Gemini API Competition, like Omni, EcoTrack, ITMZ, Jana AI, Eagle AI, and AlphaFit, demonstrating the potential of the Gemini API to enhance productivity, promote sustainability, and improve well-being.

item.title: Beyond English: How Gemma open models are bridging the language gap
item.description: AI Singapore and INSAIT teams have leveraged Gemma, a family of open-source language models, to create LLMs tailored to the unique needs of their communities, in a show of innovation and inclusivity in AI.

item.title: See the Similarity: Personalizing Visual Search with Multimodal Embeddings
item.description: Learn how to build a visual search tool using Google's Multimodal Embeddings API and explore how to apply this technology for searching images, slides, and more.

item.title: Gemini 2.0: Level Up Your Apps with Real-Time Multimodal Interactions
item.description: The Multimodal Live API for Gemini 2.0 enables real-time multimodal interactions between humans and computers, and can be used to build real-time virtual assistants and adaptive educational tools.

item.title: Build the future of home with Google Home APIs
item.description: The Google Home APIs are now in public developer beta for Android, allowing developers to build innovative smart home experiences for over 600M devices using Google's hubs, Matter infrastructure, and automation engine.

item.title: Building a better smart home
item.description: The public beta launch of Home APIs for Android allows developers to create better smart home experiences. This launch emphasizes investments in Matter to improve device connectivity and interoperability, and increase smart home accessibility.

item.title: Google AI Developers Community Spotlight Contest
item.description: The Google AI Developers Community Spotlight Contest is seeking innovative, diverse projects using Google's AI tools like Gemini and Gemma to create code repositories, videos, documentation, and more.

item.title: Vertex AI RAG Engine: A developers tool
item.description: Vertex AI RAG Engine, a managed orchestration service, streamlines the process of retrieving and feeding relevant information to Large Language Models. This enables developers to build robust, grounded generative AI apps that ensure responses are factually grounded.

item.title: Gemini 2.0: Flash, Flash-Lite and Pro
item.description: The Gemini 2.0 model family is seeing significant updates, including the release of Gemini 2.0 Flash, which is now production-ready and boasts higher rate limits, enhanced performance, and simplified pricing. Developers can also start testing an updated experimental version of Gemini 2.0 Pro today. Additionally, a new variant called Gemini 2.0 Flash-Lite, specifically designed for large-scale workloads, will be made available next week.

item.title: Imagen 3 arrives in the Gemini API
item.description: Imagen 3 – now available in Google AI Studio and the Gemini API – offers developers state-of-the-art image generation with brighter, better-composed images in diverse styles, and simplified image generation through text prompts.

item.title: Get ready for Google I/O May 20-21
item.description: Google I/O returns May 20-21. Watch the livestreams for updates on Android, AI, web, and cloud. Registration is open on the Google I/O website.

item.title: Beyond the Chatbot: Agentic AI with Gemma
item.description: A practical guide to constructing a Gemma 2-based Agentic AI system – a type of AI that can make its own decisions and use external tools to achieve goals – that can generate dynamic content for a fictional game world.

item.title: Elon Musk’s AI company, xAI, releases its latest flagship model, Grok 3
item.description:
Elon Musk’s AI company, xAI, released its latest flagship AI model, Grok 3, late Monday night, along with new capabilities in the Grok apps for iOS and the web. Grok, xAI’s answer to models like OpenAI’s GPT-4o and Google’s Gemini, can analyze images and respond to questions, and powers a number of features on Musk’s social network, X. […]

item.description: We’ve all got our health-related crosses to bear, and even if you’re currently healthy, it’s only a matter of time before entropy catches up to you. For [Markus Bindhammer], it caught …read more

item.title: A Forgotten Consumer PC Becomes a Floating Point Powerhouse
item.description: [Michael Wessel] found some of his old DOS 3D graphics software and tried to run it on an 8088 PC. The tale of adding an 8087 co-processor to speed up …read more

item.title: Thousands protest Elon Musk’s DOGE in NYC on Presidents’ Day
item.description:
More than 10,000 protesters gathered in New York City on Presidents’ Day to speak out against the current Trump administration and the actions in particular of Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE).  It was one of several protests that took place Monday in major cities across the country and came during the same long […]

item.title: Nextdoor’s Nirav Tolia thinks he can turn things around with AI; he has a lot riding on it
item.description:
Social media is often about scale, but Nextdoor bet long ago on something different: that it could grow a big business off smaller, local communities. For years, the plan worked. The 15-year-old company has long been a dominant platform for neighborhood-based conversations, connecting users for everything from lost pet alerts to local business recommendations. Then […]

item.description: The world of computer enthusiasts has over time generated many subcultures and fandoms, each of which has in turn spawned its own media. [Intric8] has shared the tale of his …read more

item.title: Measuring Local Variances in Earth’s Magnetic Field
item.description: Although the Earth’s magnetic field is reliable enough for navigation and is also essential for blocking harmful solar emissions and for improving radio communications, it’s not a uniform strength everywhere …read more

item.title: Keebin’ with Kristina: the One with the Cutting Board Keyboard
item.description: Doesn’t this look fantastic? Hard to believe it, but the base of this keyboard began life as a cutting board, and there’s a gallery to prove it. This is actually …read more

item.title: Are your noise-canceling headphones messing with your head?
item.description:
We all know headphones can be bad for your hearing if you listen to sounds too loudly in close proximity to your ears. But a BBC report suggests that a new health scare could be emerging around the noise-canceling feature that’s hugely popular in modern earphones. The article considers whether the technology could essentially be […]

item.title: The New York Times has greenlit AI tools for product and edit staff
item.description:
The New York Times is now allowing its product and editorial teams to use AI tools, which might one day write social copy, SEO headlines, and code, reports Semafor.  The news came to staff via an email, in which the publication announced the debut of its new internal AI summary tool called Echo. The New […]

item.title: The hottest AI models, what they do, and how to use them
item.description:
Confused about which AI model to use? Check out this comprehensive list of the most advanced models out there.

item.title: Trump fires hundreds of air traffic support staff as SpaceX visits FAA command center
item.description:
The Trump Administration has begun firing hundreds of Federal Aviation Administration employees who maintain critical air traffic control infrastructure, reports CNN. The firings, which began late Friday night, come as Elon Musk’s SpaceX has been tapped to help create a new air traffic control system. It’s not yet clear how many workers were fired, but the […]

item.title: Decoy Killswitch Triggers Alarm Instead
item.description: There are a few vehicles on the road that are targeted often by car thieves, whether that’s because they have valuable parts, the OEM security is easily bypassed, or even …read more

item.title: What the US’ first major AI copyright ruling might mean for IP law
item.description:
Copyright claims against AI companies just got a potential boost. A U.S. federal judge last week handed down a summary judgment in a case brought by tech conglomerate Thomson Reuters against legal tech firm Ross Intelligence. The judge found that Ross’ use of Reuters’ content to train its AI legal research platform infringed on Reuters’ […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: X is blocking links to Signal, a secure messaging platform used by federal workers
item.description:
Elon Musk’s X (formerly Twitter) is blocking links to Signal.me, a URL shortener used by the private messaging app Signal that allows users to send out a link that’s used to contact them directly through the service. The blocks, which impact direct messages, public posts, and profile pages, were first spotted by the blog Disruptionist.  […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: The “Unbreakable” Beer Glasses Of East Germany
item.description: We like drinking out of glass. In many ways, it’s an ideal material for the job. It’s hard-wearing, and inert in most respects. It doesn’t interact with the beverages you …read more

item.title: What to know about TikTok’s uncertain future in the US and the people who want to buy it
item.description:
TikTok, owned by the Chinese company ByteDance, has been at the center of controversy in the U.S. for four years now due to concerns about user data potentially being accessed by the Chinese government. Just this past month, the app experienced a temporary outage in the U.S. that left millions of users in suspense before […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: Gamemaker Polymath aims to make learning math as enjoyable as Roblox
item.description:
As gaming platforms like Roblox and Minecraft continue to grow in popularity among young children, and with platforms like YouTube consuming hours of their daily screen time, edtech companies face challenges in capturing their attention.  Polymath aims to tackle this by combining gamified mechanics inspired by these popular games with adaptive math lessons to make […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: Mistral releases regional model focused on Arabic language and culture
item.description:
The next frontier for large language models (LLMs), one of the key technologies underpinning the boom in generative AI tools, might be geographical. On Monday, Paris-based AI startup Mistral — which is vying to rival the likes of U.S.-based Anthropic and OpenAI — is releasing a model that’s a bit different from its usual LLM. […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: Olyn secures Beatles biopic for its ‘Shopify for filmmakers’
item.description:
The recent Brian Epstein biopic “Midas Man,” a film about the manager of The Beatles, debuted not on a platform like Netflix or Amazon, but on a startup that bills itself as “Shopify for filmmakers.” So what, you might ask? The answer is that the new platform, Olyn, claims to offer a new model for […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: South Korea blocks downloads of DeepSeek from local app stores
item.description:
South Korean officials on Saturday temporarily restricted Chinese AI Lab DeepSeek’s app from being downloaded from app stores in the country pending an assessment of how the Chinese company handles user data. The Personal Information Protection Commission (PIPC) said the Chinese app would be available to be downloaded once it complies with Korean privacy laws […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: Can sim drivers make the shift to F1? Max Verstappen thinks so
item.description:
Motorsports have long been a pay-to-play arena, with young drivers spending thousands of dollars just to get started in karting. Four-time Formula One champion Max Verstappen knows this all too well, but he also sees a way to change it through sim racing, a virtual form of car racing that closely replicates real-world racing. It’s […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: These researchers used NPR Sunday Puzzle questions to benchmark AI ‘reasoning’ models
item.description:
Every Sunday, NPR host Will Shortz, The New York Times’ crossword puzzle guru, gets to quiz thousands of listeners in a long-running segment called the Sunday Puzzle. While written to be solvable without too much foreknowledge, the brainteasers are usually challenging even for skilled contestants. That’s why some experts think they’re a promising way to […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: Researchers are training AI to interpret animal emotions
item.description:
Artificial intelligence could eventually help us understand when animals are in pain or showing other emotions — at least according to researchers recently profiled in Science. For example, there’s the Intellipig system being developed by scientists at the University of the West of England Bristol and Scotland’s Rural College, which examines photos of pigs’ faces […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: Broadcom, TSMC reportedly exploring deals that would split up Intel
item.description:
Broadcom and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) are separately exploring deals to take over parts of Intel, according to a report in The Wall Street Journal. Broadcom is reportedly considering an acquisition of Intel’s chip-design and marketing business, and would want a partner for the company’s manufacturing business, while TSMC is reportedly looking at controlling […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: YouTube TV reaches new deal to keep Paramount content
item.description:
After warnings that Paramount content was about to disappear from Google’s pay TV service YouTube TV, the companies announced late Saturday that they’d reached a deal that averts any disruption to channel availability. Those announcements didn’t include many specifics about the agreement, but a statement from a Paramount spokesperson said it includes “an expanded streaming […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: OpenAI tries to ‘uncensor’ ChatGPT
item.description:
OpenAI is changing how it trains AI models to explicitly embrace “intellectual freedom … no matter how challenging or controversial a topic may be,” the company says in a new policy. As a result, ChatGPT will eventually be able to answer more questions, offer more perspectives, and reduce the number of topics the AI chatbot […]

© 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.

item.title: What is device code phishing, and why are Russian spies so successful at it?
item.description: Overlooked attack method has been used since last August in a rash of account takeovers.

item.title: Solving the data doom loop
item.description: Ken Stott, Field CTO of API platform Hasura, tells Ryan about the data doom loop: the concept that organizations are spending lots of money on data systems without seeing improvements in data quality or efficiency. Their conversation touches on the challenges of data management, the impact of microservices, the importance of feedback loops in ensuring data quality, and how a data architecture that uses a supergraph would enhance data accessibility and quality.

item.title: How to harness APIs and AI for intelligent automation
item.description: APIs have steadily become the backbone of AI systems, connecting data and tools seamlessly. Discover how they can drive scalable and secure training for AI models and intelligence automation.

item.title: Financially motivated hackers are helping their espionage counterparts and vice versa
item.description: Two players who mostly worked independently are increasingly collaborative.

item.title: A distributed database that can withstand a meteor strike
item.description: Can your database handle a billion customers per month?

item.title: New hack uses prompt injection to corrupt Gemini’s long-term memory
item.description: There's yet another way to inject malicious prompts into chatbots.

item.title: “In the short term, more chaos”: What’s next for API design
item.description: Sagar Batchu, CEO and cofounder of API tooling company Speakeasy, talks with Ryan about the evolving API landscape, AI integration, the role of human technologists in an increasingly automated environment, and what people building APIs right now should keep in mind.

item.title: OpenAI’s secret weapon against Nvidia dependence takes shape
item.description: Chatbot maker partners with TSMC to manufacture custom AI chip, with plans for future iterations.

item.title: Shifting left without slowing down: Q&A with Moti Gindi of Apiiro
item.description: Can an org automate security, change its culture to up their dev velocity, and stave off burnout?

item.title: Why build your own vector DB? To process 25,000 images per second
item.description: Ben and Ryan chat with Babak Behzad, senior engineering manager at Verkada, about running a pipeline that vectorizes 25,000 images per second into a custom-built vector database. They discuss whether the speed is due to technical brains or brawn, the benefits of processing on device vs. off, and the importance of privacy when using image recognition on frames from a video camera.

item.title: DeepSeek iOS app sends data unencrypted to ByteDance-controlled servers
item.description: Apple's defenses that protect data from being sent in the clear are globally disabled.

item.title: Investing in the Stack Exchange Network and the future of Stack Overflow
item.description: Mark your calendars to learn more about Stack’s Future—Feb 26th.

item.title: Ransomware payments declined in 2024 despite massive. well-known hacks
item.description: Amount paid by victims to hackers declined by hundreds of millions of dollars.

item.title: 7-Zip 0-day was exploited in Russia’s ongoing invasion of Ukraine
item.description: Vulnerability stripped MotW tag Windows uses to flag Internet-downloaded files.

item.title: Go Module Mirror served backdoor to devs for 3+ years
item.description: Supply chain attack targets developers using the Go programming language.

item.title: 22-year-old math wiz indicted for alleged DeFI hack that stole $65M
item.description: 22-year-old Andean Medjedovic of Canada could spend decades in prison if convicted.

item.title: Will the web ever be the primary delivery system for 3D games?
item.description: Jaime Torrealba, a frontend developer currently at Push Security, joins Ryan to talk about 3D graphics and web development. Their conversation ranges from the evolution of technologies like WebGL and WebGPU to the importance of performance optimization for different devices to the frameworks available for creating 3D experiences. Jaime also explains the layers of abstraction in 3D development and shares some insight into what the future of 3D applications might look like.

item.title: Community Products Roadmap Update, January 2025
item.description: An update on recent launches and the upcoming roadmap.

item.title: Dell risks employee retention by forcing all teams back into offices full-time
item.description: "Dell may be missing out on some great talent..."

item.title: Feature flags: Theory meets reality
item.description: Ryan is joined by Fynn Glover (CEO) and Ben Papillon (CTO), cofounders of Schematic, for a conversation about managing feature flags in software development. They explore theoretical and practical applications of feature flags, the issue of tech debt, and how orgs could manage entitlements and pricing models more effectively.

item.title: New year, new features: Level up your Stack Overflow for Teams in 2025
item.description: The first release of the year is packed with features to make your knowledge-sharing community better.

item.title: Apple chips can be hacked to leak secrets from Gmail, iCloud, and more
item.description: Side channel gives unauthenticated remote attackers access they should never have.

item.title: How engineering teams can thrive in 2025
item.description: New year, new approach.

item.title: “Countries are coming online tomorrow, whole countries”
item.description: Ben and Ryan are joined by RJ Tuit, Head of UI Platform and Client Architect at ClickUp, formerly an engineering director at Microsoft. They talk about ClickUp’s vision for a comprehensive productivity platform, the complexities of measuring productivity and UX in software development, how to navigate the hype around AI, and more. Plus: What it was like scaling Microsoft’s cloud services to meet the unprecedented demands of a global workforce in quarantine.

item.title: A long, costly road ahead for customers abandoning Broadcom’s VMware
item.description: "We loved VMware, and then when Broadcom bought ‘em, we hated ‘em.”

item.title: Stack Gives Back 2024!
item.description: We’re excited to announce our 16th annual Stack Gives Back campaign donations.

item.title: How the internet changed in 2024
item.description: John Graham-Cumming, CTO of Cloudflare, joins Ben and Ryan for a conversation about the latest trends in internet usage highlighted in Cloudflare's 2024 Year in Review report.

item.title: Backdoor infecting VPNs used “magic packets” for stealth and security
item.description: J-Magic backdoor infected organizations in a wide array of industries.

item.title: Data breach hitting PowerSchool looks very, very bad
item.description: Schools are now notifying families their data has been stolen.

item.title: Researchers say new attack could take down the European power grid
item.description: Power grid in Central Europe uses unencrypted radio signals to add and shed loads.

item.title: The Internet is (once again) awash with IoT botnets delivering record DDoSes
item.description: Bigger, badder DDoSes are flooding the Internet. Dismal IoT security is largely to blame.

item.title: Why all developers should adopt a safety-critical mindset
item.description: Is anyone designing software where failures don't have consequences?

item.title: WBIT#3: Can good team dynamics make Agile obsolete?
item.description: Kyle welcomes Wes Copeland, a senior frontend engineer at Apartment Advisor, to the interview. They talk about how good test coverage helps you develop software faster, the benefits of low-fidelity prototypes, and why he prefers to avoid vibes-driven development.

item.title: Cutting-edge Chinese “reasoning” model rivals OpenAI o1—and it’s free to download
item.description: DeepSeek R1 is free to run locally and modify, and it matches OpenAI's o1 in several benchmarks.

item.title: The developer skill you might be neglecting
item.description: Ben and Ryan talk with Geoffrey (Jef) Huck, a software developer turned public speaking coach, about the importance of soft skills in the tech industry—in particular, speaking and communication skills. Their conversation touches on how Huck’s experiences with anxiety shaped his efforts to become a better communicator, practical techniques for dispelling anxiety and connecting with the audience, and the MVP approach to public speaking.

item.title: Home Microsoft 365 plans use Copilot AI features as pretext for a price hike
item.description: "Classic" plans without AI or price increases are only for current subscribers.

item.title: Microsoft patches Windows to eliminate Secure Boot bypass threat
item.description: File that neutered Secure Boot passed Microsoft's internal review process.

item.title: Robots building robots in a robotic factory
item.description: Ryan talks with Sterling Chin, a senior developer advocate at Postman, about the intersection of APIs and AI. They cover the emergence of AI APIs, the importance of quality APIs for AI integrations, and the evolving role of GraphQL in this new landscape. Sterling explains how some organizations are shifting toward an API-first development approach and talks about the future of data access in the agentic era, where APIs will play a crucial role in AI interactions.

item.title: US splits world into three tiers for AI chip access
item.description: While close US allies get unrestricted AI chip access, the rest of the world has numerical limits.

item.title: “Data is the key”: Twilio’s Head of R&D on the need for good data
item.description: In this episode, Ben and Ryan sit down with Inbal Shani, Chief Product Officer and Head of R&D at Twilio. They talk about how Twilio is incorporating AI into its offerings, the enormous importance of data quality in achieving high-quality responses from AI, the challenges of integrating cutting-edge AI technology into legacy systems, and how companies are turning to AI to improve developer productivity and customer engagement.

item.title: Failing fast at scale: Rapid prototyping at Intuit
item.description: Have an idea? Turn it into a prototype first.

item.title: WBIT #2: Memories of persistence and the state of state
item.description: Bottom line: let React do the React things.

item.title: How AI apps are like Google Search
item.description: Happy New Year! In this episode, Ryan talks with Jetify founder and CEO Daniel Loreto, a former engineering lead at Google and Twitter, about what AI applications have in common with Google Search. They also discuss the challenges inherent in developing AI systems, why a data-driven approach to AI development is important, the implications of non-determinism, and the future of test automation.

item.title: Developers want more, more, more: the 2024 results from Stack Overflow’s Annual Developer Survey
item.description: This year, technologies such as JavaScript and PostgreSQL remain most popular, Rust and Markdown remain most admired, developers are most frustrated by technical debt at work, and they don’t see AI as a threat to their jobs.

item.title: Generative AI is not going to build your engineering team for you
item.description: It’s easy to generate code, but not so easy to generate good code.

item.title: How developers (really) used AI coding tools in 2024
item.description: During the holidays, we’re releasing some highlights from a year full of conversations with developers and technologists. Enjoy! We’ll see you in 2025.

item.title: In Rust we trust? White House Office urges memory safety
item.description: Is your preferred programming language a matter of national security?

item.title: Breaking up is hard to do: Chunking in RAG applications
item.description: A look at some of the current thinking around chunking data for retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) systems.

item.title: The ghost jobs haunting your career search
item.description: There’s no silver bullet for this type of ghost.

item.title: The real 10x developer makes their whole team better
item.description: Single individuals make less of a difference to the success or failure of a technology project than you might think (and that’s a good thing).

item.title: You should keep a developer’s journal
item.description: A developer’s journal is a place to define the problem you’re solving and record what you tried and what worked.

item.title: How developer jobs (and the job market) changed in 2024
item.description: During the holidays, we’re releasing some highlights from a year full of conversations with developers and technologists. Enjoy! We’ll see you in 2025.

item.title: Balancing business and open source in 2024
item.description: During the holidays, we’re releasing some highlights from a year full of conversations with developers and technologists. Enjoy! We’ll see you in 2025.

item.title: Can a programming language implement time travel?
item.description: Computer science deals with concurrency, but what about simultaneity?

item.title: This developer tool is 40 years old: can it be improved?
item.description: Would updating a tool few think about make a diff(erence)?

item.title: Why do developers love clean code but hate writing documentation?
item.description: It's time to delegate to the robots.

item.title: Legal advice from an AI is illegal
item.description: Mark Doble, CEO of Alexi, an AI-powered litigation platform, joins Ben to talk about GenAI’s transformative effect on the legal world. Their conversation touches on the importance of ensuring accurate results and eliminating hallucinations when AI tools are used for legal work, how lawyers (like the rest of us) can adapt to GenAI, and what Alexi’s tech stack looks like.

item.title: AI agents that help doctors get paid
item.description: Dan Parsons, co-founder and Chief Experience Officer at Thoughtful AI, talks about how his company is using AI to simplify how providers get paid by insurance companies.

item.title: It’s not what you know, it’s how you know you know it
item.description: The complex relationship of give-and-take in the knowledge journey is untangled in the results from the latest Stack Overflow Knows survey.
